column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Manage Risk when Trading Stocks
#Text=Every successful business has a risk-management plan .
#Text=Stock trading is a business .
#Text=Here is how to manage risk when trading stocks .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Cover your expenses every month .
#Text=Then concentrate on achieving a steady growth in earnings .
#Text=Rather than striving for the big hit , protect your capital first and work for consistent returns .
#Text=You can take more aggressive risk with a portion of profits .
#Text=The big hits and " home runs " will still come along , but let them arrive without taking excessive risk .
#Text=Base your stock-trading business philosophy on three principles ( in order of importance ) :
#Text=Preservation of capital
#Text=Consistent profitability
#Text=Pursuit of superior returns
#Text=Preserve capital in the interests of money management .
#Text=This is the cornerstone of stock trading .
#Text=Risk is the prime concern .
#Text=Before asking , " what kind of profit can I make ? " , ask first , " what potential loss can I suffer ? "
#Text=This is astute stock-trading risk management .
#Text=A storekeeper takes a risk every time s/he stocks new merchandise .
#Text=If it does not sell , s/he will lose money .
#Text=A smart businessperson takes only risks that will not put him/her out of business , even if s/he makes several mistakes in a row .
#Text=Define your risk .
#Text=As a stock trader , you are in the business of trading .
#Text=You need to define your business risk , the most money you are willing to risk ( or lose ) on any single trade .
#Text=Here are some basic risk-management principles :
#Text=There is no standard amount of money to risk , just like there is no standard business .
#Text=Your acceptable risk level depends on the size of your trading account , your trading method and your tolerance for " pain . "
#Text=Beware of emotional trading .
#Text=Trading can be so exciting that it leads to emotional highs and lows in rapid succession .
#Text=It rarely happens that a trader will make serious money while riding an emotional roller coaster .
#Text=Emotional trading is the enemy of success .
#Text=Fear and greed can undo a stock trader .
#Text=A real professional does not get too ecstatic or too depressed about specific wins or losses .
#Text=This is a good mental state for stock trading and for life in general .
#Text=If you 're thinking about a past opportunity , you 'll miss the next one to come your way .
#Text=Focus on being the best .
#Text=The goal of a successful professional in any field is to reach his/her personal best .
#Text=You need to concentrate on trading right .
#Text=Each trade has to be handled like a surgical procedure : seriously , soberly , without sloppiness or shortcuts .
#Text=This is a stock-trading risk-management plan .
#Text=A loser cannot cut his losses quickly .
#Text=When a trade starts going sour , the loser may hope and hang on while the losses pile up ; or he may sell his position just before the market comes roaring back .
#Text=Trends emerge because most losers are alike .
#Text=They act on their gut feelings instead of using their heads .
#Text=Personal emotions do n't follow cultural backgrounds or educational levels .
#Text=Emotional traders go into risky gambles to avoid taking certain losses .
#Text=It is human nature to take profits quickly and postpone taking losses .
#Text=Emotional trading destroys otherwise intelligent traders .
#Text=Good money management and timing techniques will keep them out of the hole .
#Text=Losing traders look for a " sure thing " , hang on out of hope , and irrationally refuse to accept small losses .
